content: Thanks for the reply. It wasn't a fix, but it did give me an idea. Turns out it isn't a Thunderbird problem at all, since when I look at the same message on the mail provider's site, it has the same content. So it must be something happening further upstream. But where and why? A mystery...

content: I suggest pressing the shift key when you click 'reply' to switch you to plain text for this one message. I think that may eliminate the color issue.
creator: davidsk

content:
david said
I suggest pressing the shift key when you click 'reply' to switch you to plain text for this one message. I think that may eliminate the color issue.

Thank you for the suggestion. Yes, it eliminates the background colour. Unfortunately, it also eliminates all the HTML formatting of the included message which I am forwarding, or to which I am replying. In some cases this may be fine. In some cases, however, it ruins the included message.

I guess I should clarify my question: How can I change the background colour of my part of the reply or forwarded message which I am composing, without ruining the formatting of the included message? How can I override the background colour set by the sender in the original message, but not discard all HTML formatting?
creator: JDLH

content: Other than modifying the HTML (for which, you would need an addon), I suggest writing your reply, and then highlighting the reply, and selecting the background color option in compose menu and set to a different color. If you select a dark color, consider then changing your text to white. I agree, this is messy, and I wish people who send messages in color were sensitive to us, as receivers, who must struggle in our replies.
creator: davidsk

content: Please clarify your issue. Apparently, you sent $30 to Microsoft? For what? More information is needed, as there is no tie between Thunderbird an Microsoft. Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content: this may work: - highlight folder - click edit>select>all - right click in message list and select 'forward and redirect>as attachments' - send

content:
Hello there We have read the question We try to help

Only Thunderbird icone is freezing. Desktop icone are freezing directly.

Did you missed a recent update for the system or the recent update for Thunderbird software ? Bundeled antivirus software on the desktop can block receiving mail ,can it get turned off for a while , to notify if that is the issue?Also wrong add-ons can be deleted if you also having a quarentine option on that pc to keep infected e-mail in it turn that option off to be sure. And then check the mail again if it is there in the inbox .(or send the inbox the test mail). All these little things could come togheter and slowing the computer or icone .exe to zero below and fortenally it freezes for the user of it. Using the internet for all sort of things could do it. Be sure to have a good fast ssd.

Junkfiles can be deleted by doing a Google search on the internet and download that cleaner like cccleaner ,and the inbox could be cleaned of there junkfiles. 

Greetings Firefox volunteer .
creator: Googlethunderbird

Ovviamente facendo prima un backup -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_effettuare-una-copia-di-sicurezza-del-profilo

content:
Informazioni utili da fornire nelle richieste al forum:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
creator: @next

content:
Se in passato hai creato una password principale, allora devi inserire quella -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/password-principale-thunderbird

Se non hai mai usato la password principale, allora devi inserire la password di accesso a Windows (per Windows 10/11). Te ne accorgi perché la richiesta avviene con lo stile del sistema operativo.
creator: @next

content: There is no 'thunderbird server.' Thunderbird on your PC keeps the last password that was accepted. If you installed a fresh copy of Thunderbird on a different PC, there is no password stored. So, if you are receiving prompts for the password, the request is coming from your email host. That may indicate the password is wrong, or the configuration is wrong.
creator: davidsk

content:
Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content: There should be a 'Save' button in lower right of the customize menu.

content: Filters are stored in msgFilterRules.dat in the account subfolder of Mail or ImapMail in the profile, e.g. Mail/pop.gmail.com. The dat file can be copied between accounts.
